critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their fluffy white tails to signal danger to other deer nearby.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, even better than bloodhounds, to find food!

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to urban areas, often hunting small animals and scavenging near human habitats.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and warmth during cold weather.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are unique foxes that can climb trees to escape predators or hunt birds.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats use their sharp hearing and vision to hunt mostly at dawn and dusk.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have quills that detach easily, helping protect them from predators by causing sharp pain and irritation.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using sticks and mud to create ponds that protect their homes from predators.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges using mud and vegetation, often visible above water in wetlands.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks are excellent swimmers, often hunting underwater to catch fish, crustaceans, and small mammals.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are agile forest predators known for hunting porcupines, one of few predators that can do this!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can close their ears and nostrils underwater to swim and hunt with ease!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can remember hundreds of buried nuts using spatial memory and scent!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their pinecone caches to survive harsh winters.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have striped backs and use cheek pouches to carry food for storage in their burrows.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, shifting white in winter and brown in summer for camouflage.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails communicate danger by thumping their hind feet on the ground loudly.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have incredibly nimble front paws, almost like hands, which help them open jars and doors!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums play dead as a defense, releasing a foul smell to fool predators!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a smelly liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves from predators!

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels can glide up to 150 feet using skin flaps between their legs!

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats can catch insects mid-air using echolocation, helping control mosquito populations naturally!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control pests naturally!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like â€œWho cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?â€

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have ear tufts that help them blend into trees, not actual ears.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away predators and protect their nests.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where males and females sing to communicate.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember thousands of hiding spots for their food throughout winter!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice use their crest to signal mood, raising it when alarmed or excited.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches walk headfirst down tree trunks to find hidden insects and seeds.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers use their tiny bills to tap trees, searching for hidden insects to eat.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects and communicate with other woodpeckers nearby.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large, rectangular holes to find insects deep inside trees.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers have strong bills that help them drum on trees to find insects.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour, making them one of the fastest birds!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to duller brown in winter!

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear in winter across much of North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches sing complex songs learned from neighbors, making each birdâ€™s tune uniquely creative!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches have a sweet, raspberry-like song that brightens North American spring mornings.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour and fly short distances at 55 miles per hour!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a unique drumming sound by rapidly beating air with their wings to attract mates!

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform loud, trumpeting calls that can be heard over two miles away!

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows can recognize human faces and remember if they are friendly or threatening.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and animal calls.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks have incredible eyesight, allowing them to spot prey from over a mile away!

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks use surprise attacks, flying through dense trees to catch birds mid-air with sharp agility.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are known for their vibrant green heads and are one of the most common wild ducks worldwide!

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are one of the few ducks with colorful, iridescent plumage and bright red eyes!

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly over 1,500 miles during migration without stopping to rest!

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand motionless for minutes, patiently waiting to catch fish with their sharp beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live over 50 years and are known for their brightly colored shells!

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can live over 40 years and have powerful jaws to defend themselves underwater!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill use their colorful cheeks to attract mates during spring spawning season.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass have a unique jaw that extends beyond their eye for catching bigger prey!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow perch have sharp spines on their fins for protection against predators in freshwater habitats.

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can strike prey faster than a human eye can follow!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls during early spring nights!

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North America's largest frogs!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can jump over 20 times their body length to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 20 times their body length in a single leap!

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and are often found near water hunting amphibians and small fish.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to an hour while hunting or resting.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous snakesâ€™ patterns to protect themselves from predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, traveling from North America to central Mexico every year!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have tail-like wing extensions that help confuse predators and protect their vital body parts.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, and side to side!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings along their body when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings spread.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescence to attract mates and communicate through unique light patterns.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing, using a â€œwaggle danceâ€ to share flower locations with hive mates!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can vibrate their flight muscles to buzz-pollinate flowers, helping release pollen efficiently.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their own body length using powerful back legs!
